授業目的: This course aims to equip students with a deep understanding of migration's complex role in human welfare and international development. By examining political, climate, economic, and conflict-related migration, students will explore the root causes, implications, and potential solutions to migration challenges. Through cross-cultural collaboration and experiential learning, the course fosters critical thinking, empathy, and problem-solving skills, preparing students to engage thoughtfully with global migration issues in academic, professional, and personal contexts.
到達目標:
1. Develop nuanced understanding: Explore migration’s role in shaping human welfare and global development.

2. Analyze and critique migration cases: Investigate political, climate, economic, and conflict migration through real-world examples.

3. Promote discovery and empathy: Foster mutual understanding and cross-cultural collaboration among students.

4. Enhance skills: Build capabilities in policy analysis, teamwork, critical thinking, and public communication.

5. Ground learning in real life: Engage with migration issues through fieldwork, narratives, and real-world applications.
授業の概要・背景:
Migration is a critical issue in global development, shaping lives, societies, and policies across the world. This course examines four major types of migration—political, climate, economic, and conflict migration—focusing on their root causes, consequences, and potential solutions. Through lectures, case studies, and interactive group discussions, students will explore how migration intersects with global development challenges.

With a mix of international and local students, the course fosters cross-cultural dialogue and collaborative problem-solving. Students will gain analytical skills, practical knowledge, and teamwork experience through group projects and presentations. Key deliverables include a mid-term group report and a final presentation, emphasizing the integration of theory and practice.
授業方法:
This course balances three modes of learning:

  • Independent Learning: Students access resources (readings, documentaries, and case studies) via LUNA or Y-Drive, submitting three 800-word reviews on selected materials by Week 10.
  • Collaborative Discussion: Class sessions emphasize peer-led discussions, debates, and group work based on pre-assigned materials and emerging global issues.
  • Experiential Fieldwork: Students will connect theoretical concepts to real-world observations during events like EXPO 2025 or regional cultural experiences in Osaka-Kobe, utilizing insights for course projects.

Ideas, Insights and Conceptual & Analytical Framework Illustration.
第3回: Why / How to / Under What (Socio-Cultural Economics) Conditions for, Migration & Who are Moving (vis-à-vis those Staying-behind)?
第4回: What are the Attractions for Migration – the Differential “Pulling” Forces & Socio-Economic and Political Dynamics for (potential) Migrants & their Families.
第5回: Escaping from What / Which Society, Whom? The “Pushing” (or “Kicking-Out”) Forces & Dynamics – Comparative Case Studies: Re-Examination of Evidence versus Myths.
第6回: When & How: Timing & Means of the “Escape” – The Path-or Means-dependent Modus Operandi of Moving (as individuals, ethnic-group or en-masse): Comparative Geo-Historical Case Studies on Out-(in-)Migration.
第7回: Pattern of Migrations in Different Historical Times and Geopolitical Spaces: Comparative Case Studies: Evidence versus Myths.
第8回: New Global Division of Labours: Opportunities for Skill- (illegal) Migration? Comparative Case Studies: Manufacturing of Luxury Brand-Products, juxtaposing globalizing (contractual) “Domestic” Caring of Family Members.
